name: Concurrent and Parallel Programming
description:
Calendar Description for CS 343
                An introduction to concurrent and parallel programming, with an emphasis on language constructs. Major topics include exceptions, coroutines, atomic operations, critical sections, mutual exclusion, semaphores, high-level concurrency, deadlock, interprocess communication, process structuring, shared memory, and distributed architectures. Students will learn how to structure, implement, and debug concurrent programs.
                
                    
                        View requirements for CS 343
learningOutcomes: Structure, implement and debug concurrent programs.

materials.title: Understanding Control Flow: Concurrent Programming Using μC++
materials.notes: Provided to students enrolled in the course.

policies: Assignments are due on the due-date at the time specified on the top of the assignment (usually 22:00).
2 assignments may be up to 2 days late; except for the last assignment if due on the last day of classes.

Short term absences are not accepted as a way to extend an assignment deadline. If you have a medical or personal issue affecting your ability to hand in an assignment or attend an examination, contact the ISC, and accomodations will be made, such as extending the assignment due-date a few days.
An assignment not handed in receives a mark of 0, unless there is a documented reason.
A copy of the documented reason must be given to the Instructional Support Coordinator.
The weight of the missing assignment is distributed across the other assignments.

name: Computer Networks
description:
Calendar Description for ECE 358
                This course is a comprehensive introduction to computer networks. The focus is on the concepts, the protocols, and the fundamental design principles that have contributed to the success of the internet. Topics include history of the Internet, transmission media and technologies, switching and multiplexing, protocols and layering, wired and wireless LAN (local-area networks), congestion/flow/error control, routing, addressing, internetworking (Internet) including TCP (transmission control protocol).
                
                    
                        View requirements for ECE 358
learningOutcomes: Analyze and solve networking problems from the perspective of a network engineer. [2a, 2b, 2c, 3c, 6a, 12a]
Explain the structure and operation of the main components of the Internet. [1c, 1d, 7b, 12b, 9a]
Explain and apply key networking protocols and design principles. [1c, 1d, 4a, 4b, 8b, 10a]
Analyze and evaluate transport-layer protocols, with emphasis on TCP and retransmission mechanisms. [2b, 2c, 3, 9b, 12c]
Apply IP layer concepts including addressing, routing, and related mechanisms—to real-world scenarios. [1d, 2a, 5a, 5c, 11a, 9a]
Describe and compare Local Area Network (LAN) technologies and their underlying Layer 2 protocols. [1c, 1d, 2c, 7a, 8a, 10b]
Model and evaluate networking scenarios using network simulation tools. [5a, 5b, 5c, 3a, 4c, 4f, 6b, 11b]
Use basic network utilities (e.g., ping, traceroute, netstat, Wireshark) to diagnose and troubleshoot network issues. [3b, 5a, 5c, 6a, 6b, 7c, 12d]

materials.title: Computer Networking, 8/e (7/e or 6/e are also acceptable), James F. Kurose, Keith W. Ross.

policies: If you miss the midterm without a valid reason, that midterm earns a score of zero.
If you miss the midterm for a valid reason, your final exam weight will be increased accordingly. There will be no “make up” midterm exams.
The instructors determines whether or not a reason for missing a lab deadline or exam is deemed to be valid.
The instructor reserves the right to change the grading scheme (and to curve the final grade) as long as no student would do worse with the new grading scheme.

The instructor also reserves the right to use alternative grading schemes in special circumstances. For example, if an accommodation is necessary, an alternative grading scheme may be used for individual students

Late labs will not be accepted without a verification of illness or other UW-approved documentation. Contact the lab instructor as soon as possible if you must miss a lab component for a documented reason. Note that the 48 hour self declaration absence cannot be applied to lab components.

name: Introductory Astronomy

schedule.time: Assignment 1Recommended Due Date: Wednesday, September 10, 2025 at 11:59 AMActual Due Date: Wednesday, September 17, 2025 at 11:59 AM

description:
Calendar Description for SCI 238
                A survey course in astronomy. The solar system, the Sun and planets, stars, the Milky Way, galaxies, and cosmology.
                
                    
                        View requirements for SCI 238
learningOutcomes: Explain historical and conceptual developments in astronomy, including changes in object classification, measurement techniques, and the role of observational evidence in shaping scientific models.
Evaluate the capabilities and limitations of astronomical instruments and explain how technological advances have expanded our understanding of the universe.
Interpret astronomical data and visualizations to infer properties of planets, stars, galaxies, and other celestial objects.
Apply laws of physics to analyze celestial motion, orbital dynamics, and energy transfer in astronomical systems.
Develop an appreciation for and understanding of how the careful application of scientific principles helps us understand the world around us.

materials.title: Mastering Astronomy
materials.notes: You are required to purchase the subscription, as your weekly assignments are done on this site (this can be purchased as a package with textbook)

materials.title: The Cosmic Perspective (10th Ed.)
materials.notes: Highly recommended, as the exams for this course are "open book"

policies: Note that assignments CANNOT be submitted after their due times. Please check the schedule above for assignment due dates.
Midterms will not generally be rescheduled, except in cases of severe illness or personal trauma.
Attendance at the in-person final exam is mandatory, except in cases of severe illness or personal trauma.

Student travel plans are not considered acceptable grounds for granting an alternative examination time. Any medical exceptions must be documented by a signed medical note from a doctor or clinic, indicating the date and severity of the illness, and will only be accepted at the instructor’s discretion. Exams will not be excused for minor complaints. Students with chronic health problems should consult with the AccessAbility Services for alternate exam arrangements.
Please consult the Accommodation for illness or other extenuating circumstances.

name: Introduction to Feedback Control
description:
Calendar Description for SE 380
                Introduction to control systems. Advantages of closed-loop feedback systems. The role of the system mathematical model. Block diagrams and signal flow graphs. The basic control system design problem, stability in control systems. Frequency response analysis techniques. Root-locus analysis. Elementary lead-lag compensation.
                
                    
                        View requirements for SE 380
learningOutcomes: Explain what feedback control is and why it is useful.
Understand mathematical models of dynamical systems (in both time and frequency domain).
Draw and interpret block diagrams of interconnected feedback systems.
Use a graphical tool (Simulink) for simulations.
Understand why we use transfer functions to model systems and controllers, as well as frequency domain analysis of closed-loop systems.
Understand the concept of stability in the context of feedback control systems and methods to determine if a system is stable.
Apply the modeling, analysis, design, and implementation techniques of the course to a lab experiment.

materials.title: Chris Nielsen, ECE 380 Course notes.
materials.notes: Available for free on the course's Learn page, courtesy of Prof. Chris Nielsen, ECE, U. Waterloo.

policies: Late content will not be graded.

name: Design Project Planning
description:
Calendar Description for SE 390
                Students undertake a substantial customer-driven group project as part of the SE390/490/491 design-project sequence covering all major phases of the software-engineering lifecycle. Lectures describe expectations and project-planning fundamentals. Students form groups, decide on a project concept, complete a project-approval process, develop high-level requirements for the project, perform a risk assessment, develop a test plan, and complete a first-iteration prototype. Social, legal, and economic factors are considered.
                
                    
                        View requirements for SE 390
learningOutcomes: Identify problems worth solving through software
Make strategic decisions in problem definition (such as scoping and pivoting)
Implement effective teamwork strategies
Effectively plan and estimate project work
Identify the strengths, weaknesses, and styles of co-workers
Apply software requirements engineering, design, and implementation practices on a team project
Validate project ideas and designs
Effectively communicate the progress and results of team projects

materials.title: SE Capstone Design Project Handbook by Derek Rayside
materials.notes: Available from the capstone website:  https://ece.uwaterloo.ca/~se_c...

materials.title: Past project abstracts and videos
materials.notes: Available from the capstone website:  https://ece.uwaterloo.ca/~se_c...

policies: Late Submissions: Late deliverable submissions will not be accepted.
Extra Credit: In this class, there will be no opportunities to earn extra credit. Make-up projects will not be offered under any circumstances.

Attendance & Illness: Attendance of the scheduled team meetings with the instructors and presentations is mandatory for all team members. Attendance of the guest lectures is not mandatory, but highly encouraged and appreciated and rewarded by bonus points. It would be simply unfair to the guest speakers to have low attendance.
If you feel ill, you should seek appropriate medical attention. If you miss a team meeting with the instructor for health reasons, you need notify me, explaining the reason.

name: Software Design and Architectures
description:
Calendar Description for SE 464
                Introduces students to the design, implementation, and evolution phases of software development. Software design processes, methods, and notation. Implementation of designs. Evolution of designs and implementations. Management of design activities.
                
                    
                        View requirements for SE 464
learningOutcomes: propose and analyze software architectures.
explain the strengths and weaknesses of various architectural styles and design patterns / techniques.
communicate and rationalize architectural and design decisions.
ideate, justify, and implement software designs.
evaluate, compare, and contrast different architectures and designs.

materials.title: Labs: Git, AWS, a bunch of tech

policies: Late policy: 20% deduction per day

name: Logic and Computation
description:
Calendar Description for CS 245
                Logic as a tool for representation, reasoning, and computation. Propositional and predicate logic. Formalizing the notions of correct and incorrect reasoning, defining what is computable, and exploring the limits of computation. Godel's Incompleteness Theorem. Applications of logic to computer science.
                
                    
                        Prereq: (One of CS 136, 138, 146), MATH 135; Honours Mathematics students only. Antireq: CS 245E, PMATH 330, ECE 208, SE 212
learningOutcomes: Formalize English sentences into properly formed formulas in the propositional and first-order logic and, conversely, interpret such formulas in English
Formalize the notion of correct reasoning and proof, and be able to construct formal proofs
Realize the limitation of formal proof systems
Understand the applications of logic to computer science
